They then roll dice and consult a table to determine the effects of their weapon fire, recording damage on their cards.

The game ends when a player has inflicted 10 points of damage on their opponent's starfighter. A solo game variant is available, dictating the opponent's actions by dice rolls.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Relative Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: PowerMage 54
description:
From the PowerMage website: PowerMage 54 is a stand-alone card game where players use superheroes (known as powermages) to defeat their opponents.

Through the strategic use of attack items to decrease points, defense items to block , health items to increase points, powermages’ abilities, and the unique specialty thump cards, players slug it out to determine who is the last powermage standing.

name: Witch's Coming!
description:
Witch's Coming! is a game about a Halloween night in which one player plays the Witch team and the other the villager team. The witches mingle with the children in costumes, enter the villager's houses, and cast curses. If all three witches manage to get into the villagers' houses before sunrise, the witch wins; if the villagers manage to stop that, the villagers win. To do this, the villager player needs to get all three children into the villagers' houses or chase away the witches until the sun rises.

The witch player and the villager player take alternating turns, starting with the witch. Once they've each taken a turn, they check whether someone has won, and if not, the game continues with the witch taking her turn first.

name: Spooky  Tales
description:
The box contains two different decks of cards for two different games. They have the potential to be scary, but are for ages 8 and up.

One is a 76 card storytelling game, which includes text cards for beginnings, segues and endings. Black and white line drawings depict characters, settings, things, actions and embellishments. A storyteller uses up their cards by putting these elements into their story. Other players can interrupt and continue the story themselves by playing a card or using a steal token.

The second deck is called Vampire Rises, and consists of 24 cards: 4 vampires, 17 villagers, 1 seer, 1 garlic farmer and 1 vampire hunter. It is played like games such as Werewolf. The roles are handed out secretly. Villagers desire to kill all the vampires. Vampires prey on the villagers. The seer helps the villagers discover who the vampires are.

Also in the gamebox is a large flashlight which has button for sound effects: thunder, wolf, scream, and laugh.

name: Pirate Lords
description:
Galleons overloaded with gold are the desired catch for sea wolfs. The most influential pirate lords have gathered at the port to put together a team of sailors to board the traders' fleet. Seizing the gold is just half of the business, however; it’s much harder to…share it.

In Pirate Lords, you gather masters of saber, steering wheel, and pistol under your flag — then passionately bargain with other players for the booty. Only in unity can pirates overpower a trader's defenses. Will you show greediness or generously share rewards? Your victory in the game depends on timely decisions.

name: Triple Flips 5: Police Rescue
description:
Triple Flips 5 includes Kidnap and Rescue, Spy Against Spy, and Runaway School Bus.


Kidnap and Rescue is a capture-the-flag game for 2-4 players. Move to the captive, become the captive, and put your own pawn home. Everyone else continues to try to get the captive, which is now you. If someone catches you, they become the captive, and you re-enter from home. Try to get the captive home!



Spy Against Spy is another intentionally lopsided 2-player game, but this time the effect is a little more like American football. The defender merely obstructs the offender as much as possible to minimize her progress over the course of ten turns.



Runaway School Bus is a 1-player timed race, with the interesting twist that the timing is staged. There are five points along the bus's path where you can intercept it. You merely need to progress, by die roll of course, along your linear path more quickly than the bus to maximize your score. This game features a small misprint, since if you don't count the picture of a schoolbus as a space for the bus, getting 5 points is quite literally impossible. You can't get 14 out of two rolls of a six-sided die - it's low enough odds on three rolls.

name: Nature Enjeux Monde
description: Learn about vegetation, animals and minerals in our world. No need to be a pro, you can learn as you play with 2,400 questions, miming and drawing.

name: Fill the Flower Pot!
description:
From the rulebook:
Whoever, with a good overview and a bit of luck, can bring the
three flowers to the flower pot of the corresponding color first, wins the game

This is one of Haba's "Suitcase" games: small childrens games in a metal suitcase suitable for travel (all magnetic pieces).
mechanics: Pattern Recognition, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Bicycle Race
description:
Bicycle Race is a fast-playing 18-card microgame of bluff and luck for 4–6 players, from designer Sebastian Bleasdale.

You’re a cyclist competing for position in the peloton, but overtaking the leaders isn’t easy. You’ll need skill in bluffing and a healthy dose of luck. Can you out-think the other riders and reach the head of the pack in time to seize victory?

name: FRICO
description:
FRICO is the most popular game of the culture war that is ironically playful parochial controversy that often pits the city of Udine and Trieste on the market. The military confrontation-humorous takes shots of traditions and cultural elements characteristic of the two cities, the background scenario with a regional part of the municipalities of Friuli, Trieste across the districts, separated from Bisiacheria, neutral buffer zone.
The aim is the conquest of the region's most sought-after in the world: the Friuli Venezia Giulia.

The Turn of each player consists of:

Draw a card from their decks of belonging;
Acquire reinforcements through the number of territories held;
Moving a group of armies in another adjacent territory
Attack other players using a simple rule of combat comparison the result of a dice for the attacker and one defender, the higher of the two wins. Players can stick with the desired frequency.
Use the cards to take advantage or disadvantage the enemy.



FRICO' è il più popolare gioco di guerra culturale che tratta con ironia la scherzosa diatriba campanilistica che spesso contrappone le città di Udine e Trieste disponibile sul mercato. Il confronto bellico-umoristico avviene a colpi di tradizioni ed elementi culturali caratteristici delle due città, sullo sfondo lo scenario regionale con da una parte i comuni friulani, dall'altra i rioni triestini, separati dalla Bisiacheria, zona cuscinetto neutrale.
L'obiettivo è la conquista della regione più ambita al mondo: il Friuli Venezia Giulia.

Il Turno di ogni giocatore è composto da:

Pescare una delle carte del proprio mazzo di appartenenza;
Acquisire rinforzi attraverso il numero di territori tenuto;
Spostamento di un gruppo di eserciti in un altro territorio adiacente
Attaccare altri giocatori usando una semplice regola di combattimento di confronto il risultato di un dado per l’attaccante e uno per il difensore,il più alto tra i due vince. I giocatori possono attaccare con la frequenza desiderata.
Usare le carte per avvantaggiarsi o svantaggiare il nemico.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Team-Based Game

name: Office Space: The Game
description:
This is a secret missions game to play at work. It was inspired by one of our favorite movies, Office Space. If you love the movie then you’ll enjoy all the in-jokes in the game. But it’s still a great game even if you’ve never seen it.

It works like this: draw six secret missions each and the first player to complete three missions wins. The missions involve tricking your colleagues into doing things without them realizing, including stealing Milton’s famous red stapler.

Work might suck sometimes, but this game will make it suck a little less.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: Clue Diced!
description:
Ready, Set, Roll! It's a different way to play the Clue game! Unlike the classic Clue game, this Diced edition has no gameboard and players roll to find out whodunit. This fun game has players rolling the Suspect dice and the Bonus die, getting closer to guessing the culprit as opponents reveal their cards. When a player is ready to crack the case, they secretly look at the cards placed inside the Case File envelope to reveal who was the brains and who was the brawn behind the crime. The Clue Diced game is a compact and portable game making it a great game for travel and for on-the-go play.

—description from the publisher

Put simply: Instead of moving pawns around the board and making a guess in a room (as in classic Clue), players simply roll 4 dice and pick a combination of people and roles to gain information about.

Includes 2 levels of difficulty.
Includes game case, 18 suspect cards, 4 dice, dice labels, case file envelope, suggestion board, detective pad, and game rules.

name: James Bond
description:
James Bond is a game of speed and frantic simultaneous action that takes under five minutes to play. It is played with a standard poker deck with Jokers removed. Each player tries to be the first to transform the piles of cards they have been dealt into sets of four-of-a-kind. They do this by exchanging cards from their piles with the four face-up cards in the center of the table. A player may only hold and look at one of his piles at a time, and may only exchange one card at a time with the one of the cards on the table. There are no turns; everyone works at once. The four face-up cards on the table are thus constantly changing along with the makeup of the players' piles. The first player to have converted all his piles to four-of-a-kind is the winner.

James Bond is also known as Atlantis or Chanhassen. Players must say the game's name when they've finished in order to win.

Note: The date and origins of the game are unknown, although it seems to be recent, perhaps as recent as 2009.
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Speed Matching

name: Gray Matter
description: Play the game that works your whole brain! You’ll need to think hard, strategize harder and use lots of common sense to win. You’ll travel the game board, landing on spaces that direct what kind of questions you’ll be asked, what your penalty will be if you get it wrong and whether you get to wager on your ability to get it right. Try one? Your category choices are Food Facts and Water Works. Food Facts? Great. Here’s your question: “Which was the first company to introduce frozen foods to the consumer market: a) Green Giant, b) Pillsbury, c) Birdseye or d) Dare.” The answer? “In the early 1900’s, Clarence Birdseye invented a system to freeze food.” Game comes with 480 question cards, game board, 4 playing pieces, a die and instruction sheet.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Mongolian Goat Rodeo
description:
The object of Mongolian Goat Rodeo is to grab the goat from one corner of the play area, then carry it down to the opposite corner, around a goat post, and back to the starting location. There's only one goat, so players will tussle over who has control. The object of the game is to get the most victory points. Three points are up for grabs in the rodeo and up to ten points are available from bragging rights afterwards.

On a turn, a player rolls 2d6 for each of his three riders to determine how far they can go. A ruler is used to measure the distance moved. If a rider ends his move adjacent to the goat, he can tussle for it. To do that, the player must explain how he takes possession of the goat. Based on the quality of the story, another player judges the likelihood on a d6 roll of the active player taking possession. "Unexpected events" are handled similarly. At any point a player may spend a coin from their hand and declare one. They describe what happens and then another player decides its likelihood.

Once the goat it safely back to the starting point, the players may spend any remaining coins, with each coin granting an argument to try to gain more victory points. These may relate to things that happened during the rodeo or to post-rodeo festivities that would make a team look better in the eyes of the spectators. Once all the coins are gone, the winner is determined.

The first edition of Mongolian Goat Rodeo (2006) was a board game, while the second edition (2013) is a card game in which players need to supply their own dice, ruler and coins in order to play. The designer has also published free "miniatures game" rules that can be played using any mounted figures. See the Community Wiki section, below.

name: Have At Thee
description:
Have At Thee is a card game of multi opponent sword fighting for 2 to 6 players aged 9+. It is a fast paced game which lasts between 20 and 40 minutes.

Players attack their opponents who then defend against the attacks, trying to avoid taking the most damage.

The game was conceived of and written by Richard Williams and Dave Skidmore, with further help, feedback and play testing from Ed Boreham and Calne Gamers Group.

name: Tactico: Football Edition
description:
Tactico is a football game where you move around a board, where the spaces allow you to buy players, collect income from opponents where you own a majority of cards in a particular position. and challenge others to a match. The matches utilise a special dice and the team with the better players in the positions rolled on the dice are likely to win the match. Wins gain 3 points and draws 1 point. You win the game by either being the first player to amass 10 points through playing matches or by bankrupting the other players.

From the official website

Tactico recreates all the action, excitement, ups and downs of a football championship without complex rules. Go head-to-head with a single opponent or challenge the entire family.

It can be played by hardened fanatics or casual fans on an equal footing. The rules can be learned in a matter of minutes and anyone aged 6-80 could be lifting the champions cup with the right decisions and a lucky roll of the unique football shaped die.Spend your clubs money wisely to build the team that gives you the best chance against the rival players.

Collect players of matching colors to make your opponents pay millions of pounds into your coffers. Or try and build a diverse team of the most skilled players that will prove a winning formula on the pitch.

The choice is yours and what tactics you employ will decide how the game unfolds.

name: 'Nam Diary
description:
Nam Diary is a "mini-sim" published in Panzerschreck Magazine #6 (Summer 2001) and later made available as a stand alone game.

From the introduction:
It is late afternoon in mid-April, 1968. On patrol near the DMZ, Pfc. Bomar Henry is about to get his first taste of a Vietnam firefight. Will he live to tell about it?

'Nam Diary is a short and very simple game of strategy for two players. One player controls seven US soldiers, while the other controls eleven North Vietnamese (NVA) soldiers. The game includes a map depicting a jungle trail, a few dozen unmounted counters, and brief rules.
mechanics: Hexagon Grid, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation

name: Lilo & Stitch Ohana Game
description: In this children's game, based on the Disney film, players try to bring David, Nani, Lilo and Stitch together as a family. On your turn, you roll the die and move the number of spaces indicated. You then draw a card from the deck that depicts a character. When you land on a Scene space (depicting a scene from the movie), you may trade in David, Nani, and Lilo cards for a puzzle piece. You must turn in a complete set of Jumba, Pleakly, and Grand Councilwoman cards to receive the Stitch puzzle piece. Cobra Bubbles and Captain Gantu cards let you take an extra turn or steal an opponent's card respectively. The first player to land on the Final Scene space with a completed four-piece puzzle (depicting the happy family) wins the game.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Genie's Banquet
description:
His stomach is growling, so the hungry genie in the lamp is demanding that you serve him a crazy volume of dishes! You and your teammates play a hand of cards to try to satisfy his unreasonable orders.

Genie's Banquet is a cooperative card game, and to win all players must work together to clear four rounds, with four orders being placed in each round — and the later the round, the more difficult the combinations of order cards that appear.

Each order card features a few requirements, such as "kind of food" and "number of dishes", while each dish card in the hand of players shows one kind (hamburger, pasta, curry, chicken) and one number (1-8). Each turn, you play a hand to satisfy the genie's order card requirement, and when all of the requirements are satisfied, it can be cleared. However, you can't tell your teammates which cards you have; you can say only things like, "I want to use a hand for this order!" You and your team can play only limited hands (eight cards at first) in each round, so you must play them efficiently.

To overcome these difficulties, you can cooperate with your teammates to clear order cards "in a row"; doing so gets you a magical jewel that can grant various useful magic to support you during the game.

With your wisdom and this magical power, let's satisfy the genie's crazy stomach, after which you might finally hear him say the magic words: "You have three wishes..."
publishers: こたつパーティー (Kotatsu Party)

name: Monopoly: Newcastle & Gateshead
description: The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Newcastle & Gateshead, in the United Kingdom.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Hauling Astronauts
description:
There’s not much money to be made on Mars, but there’s plenty to be made getting people there.

The population of Mars is just under 2,000 people ‐ mostly scientists, some entrepreneurs, and a handful of very wealthy tourists. And this population is growing every week.

Hauling Astronauts (or Hauling A’, for short) is a game that pits two space transport companies against each other as they try to make the most money transporting astronauts to Mars.

Players roll dice with the pips representing astronauts, then place the die one by one on a shared grid. By arranging the dice in a way that matches their Transport Ships ("5 or less", "6 - 10", "even", "odd", etc.), players attempt to maximize their profits. Additional bonuses can be obtained by delivering their passengers to destination docks that also have defined ranges ("3", "4 - 7", etc.).

Hauling Astronauts was recognized with the following awards from the PnP Game Design Awards 2016:
- Runner up "Best Art & Design"
- Runner up "Best Small Build"
- Honorable Mention "Most Innovative"

name: Lucky Captain
description: This page does not exist. You can edit this page to create it.

name: Elvish Checkers
description:
Blending elements of checkers and backgammon, this unique game pits your thinking ability against that of your opponent. Use your "Stone Guardian" along with strategic blocks and traps to exit your pieces off the board first.

You can find a copy of our updated rules here: http://threesagesgames.com/Boardgames/.

name: Spiel Mini
description:
Smaller than Reinhold Wittig's Spiel, tinier than the Spiel expansion 55, Abacusspiele presents Wittig's Spiel Mini, which consists of a pyramidal base, twenty dice of the same color, and a plastic lid to keep everything in place.

Like Wittig's Spiel, Spiel Mini is a game system in which users are encouraged to create and submit their own dice games to Abacusspiele for inclusion in the produced version of the game. Spiel Mini will initially be released at Spiel 2011 in a "barebones" edition that includes all of the components and none of the rules.

Reimplements:

Spiel

name: Rapidoodle
description:
You’ve got four basic shapes and only ONE MINUTE, can you doodle something different over each one? Rapidoodle is the fast-moving picture drawing game where drawing different wins!

Players all start with the same four shapes, then doodle over them to create four different pictures. If no one else doodled the same picture, you score! Rapidoodle challenges players to be original while fighting the clock. When creativity is king, will your doodles be one-of-a-kind? The more creative you are the more you win.

name: DUNE: Return to the Sietch
description:
The setting is Arrakis, Dune the desert world. You are a group of Fremen out on the sands. On your return journey to the sietch a member of your party spots worm sign on the horizon, you run towards home, but before you know it the massive sandworm has headed you off and now stands between your group and the sietch.

Basically:
Get as many of your group as possible safely to the sietch. To do this you must avoid the moving sandworm. You receive points for each Fremen you return safely to the sietch. Aside from the regular members in your party are 2 elders and 1 sietch leader. These score more points if returned safely to the sietch.

name: Colis Party
description:
Try to deliver your packet as soon as possible to mailman Johnny.

Each player chooses a card (indicating means of mail delivery transport) from his hand and passes it face down to his right of left neighbour (direction is given by Johnny the mailman). When all players have a hidden card in front of them, they turn the cards at the same time. The card in front of each player indicates which combination he/she should make. They have to see how much identical cards are revealed by other players, and how much identical cards they have on their hand. This indicates on which number they have to tap (2, 3 of 4) as soon as possible. If they see 5 identical cards, they shout "timbré" (=stamped).

Players who tapped rightfully at 2, 3 of 4 can take pieces of a packet. They get 2 cards (showing parts of a postpacket) from the deck, keep 1 and discard the other one. The player who tapped the 3 can make, after choising from two cards, an additional move: steal a card from an other player. The player who could tap the 4 can choose a piece (out of two cards), steal another and gets the mailman. He/she also decides in which direction the cards are given in the next round. The players who tapped wrongfully, must discard a card from their packet.

If a player can show 5 identical cards, he shouts "timbré". He'll be the only one playing this round. He takes 5 cards from the deck, keep 1 and discard 4, steals a card and takes the mailman. The other players must discard a piece (card) of their packet.

For the next round players take the card in front of them in their hands and play a hidden card to the right or left player, as isntructed by the (new) mailman.

As soon as a player had his 6 pieces (cards) of the packet AND the mailman, he/she wins!

name: OrgoglioNerd: Area Stampa
description:
An italian party card game, where you impersonate a journalist who wants to make a career to become the new head chief of the redaction OrgolioNerd ("NerdProud") and overthrows the current evil director Rinoceronte ("Rhino").

You can accumulate ego points in three different ways: with good manners, bad manners or appealing to your nerd culture.
You can write news articles, or steal that from your opponents, each method is permissible for the win!

From the back of the box (Italian):

Grazie ad OrgoglioNerd: Area Stampa potrete vivere l'ebrezza di far parte della redazione nerdescha più nota d'Italia!

Quali redattori di OrgoglioNerd avrete 3 modi per chiudere i vostri articoli prima che vengano caricati su uno dei portali di nerdinformazione più cliccati di sempre: con le Buone, con le Cattive oppure semplicemente facendo appello alla vostra profonda cultura da fanboy di fumetti & co. Nessuno dei 3 modi di fare può definirsi migliore degli altri, bisogna sapersi adattare per soddisfare i capricci dell'incontentabile caporedattore, il Rinoceronte. Riuscire a soddisfarlo non sarà per niente facile e pezzo dopo pezzo accumulerete un Ego tale da farvi pensare che sia possibile scalzarlo dalla sua ingombrante posizione per reclamarne il posto... Ci riuscirete? Beh, in bocca al Rinoceronte!

OrgoglioNerd: Area Stampa è un gioco di carte in cui vestirete i panni di uno dei redattori del portale. Ciascuno di voi sarà caratterizzato da un potere unico legato alla vostra particolare personalità da nerd che durante il gioco potrete sfruttare per interagire con i vostri avversari. Per vincere dovrete riuscire a conquistare 3 punti Ego, ottenuti chiudendo gli articoli che il mazzo di carte al centro del tavolo vi proporrà di volta in volta, oppure fregando il pezzo ai vostri avversari. Entrambi i metodi sono più che leciti, starà a voi risolverli con le Buone, con le Cattive o a Modo vostro. Una volta raggiunto il terzo Ego otterrete il titolo di Rinoceronte, ma per vincere la partita dovrete dimostrare di esserne degni sfidando i vostri avversari e abbattendoli uno ad uno a colpi di mood. Il nuovo Rinoceronte sarà colui che riuscirà a dimostrarsi degno del titolo di predatore ultimo e di leader indiscusso della redazione!

Prodotto realizzato in collaborazione con la redazione di OrgoglioNerd.

Elementi del gioco:
55 carte
6 segnalini Ego
1 regolamento

name: Hexe, Tier … wer fehlt denn hier?
description:
To start Hexe, Tier … wer fehlt denn hier?, divide the cards evenly among all players, with these cards lying face up on the table in front of each player. Each card shows a young witch flying on a broom, with one or more animals accompanying her.

On a turn, one player rolls the two dice, which show various animals on them. If different animals show on the dice, then each player can turn face down all cards on which these two animals are depicted. If the same animal shows on both dice, then you have to look for only this animal on your cards. Whoever turns all their cards face down first wins the round, claiming all the face-up cards remaining in front of other players. Players then turn all their cards face up and begin a new round, which will likely favor those with fewer cards since they have less to flip over to win. At the end of three rounds, whoever has the most cards in front of them wins.

name: Der Tiger ist los
description:
Cooperative game in which the players try to close three zoo gates to prevent the tiger and her cub from escaping.

Players roll a die for movement and a color die to determine which way the tiger moves. Each player has 2 pawns and you can always move your pawn either direction, so a player has four choices of possible moves with each roll. It takes two pawns to close a gate, but players can collaborate to close a gate. The tiger is moved to a gate. Once a gate is closed, the tigers will never move toward it.
The mother tiger is trying to find her child and she moves automaticly each turn towards an open gate. When the mother tiger finds her cub, the players lose the game. When the players close the gates on time, they win the game.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Millionen Poker
description: In the underworld a hot struggle for the inheritance of Big Max is brewing. Five suitcases, each with $1 million needs a godfather to decide the quarrel. The players take the role of informant crash the underworld. But they place specialized stool pigeons, have pull with cheating gamblers, or threaten with the Saturday night specials.
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Set Collection, Take That

name: Pandora's Box
description:
A timeless game of psychology and curiosity

To Hesiod and the Ancient Greeks, womanhood began with Pandora. Her very name meant she was gifted in every way by the gods: beautiful, wise, musical, persuasive, confident . . . and curious. She was given a jar that contained all of the world’s evils, and also one good spirit, Hope. In the end, she chose to open it, and set the course for humanity.

Pandora's Box provides a simple and deep abstract party game for a group of players to analyze how well they know the strategic planning of their friends. Each player receives a few white and black stones (good and evil spirits) that they drop into a box in the center of the play area. They may also switch the stones in their hands with other players throughout the game. When someone drops her last stone into Pandora's Box, the box is opened, its contents revealed and taken by the player who opened it, and each player scores points for white stones in hand and loses a point for black stones in hand.

Though it sounds incredibly simple, the game is fast, deep, thrilling, and offers tremendous psychological fun and unexpected results. Despite having no random elements, it has plenty of hidden information that makes each game play out differently.

Pandora’s Box is offered as an entry to the Thousand Year Game Design Challenge.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Bluffing, Educational, Party Game

name: Hanafuda Hawaii Style
description:
A variant of the traditional Japanese card game 'Hanafuda', this deck of cards is specifically designed for the Hawaiian Style game known as 'Sakura'. Two to six people can play, either individually or as teams of two.

The 48 cards are divided into twelve 'hiki' or suits, each corresponding to a specific month. The four cards in each hiki have 20, 10, 5, and zero points. The objective of the game is to accumulate the most points by matching cards. The highest possible score is 240 points.

After shuffling and cutting the deck, the 'oya' (dealer) deals cards counter-clockwise to the players; the number of cards dealt differs depending on the number of players. The oya then plays a number of cards in the center of the table, known as the "field". The remainder of the deck is set nearby as a draw stack.

Play begins with the oya and moves counter-clockwise. The player draws a card from her hand and places it in the field. If the played card matches the hiki (suit) of a card in the field, the player places her card on top of the matching card to show everyone the match. She then picks up both cards and places them face-up in a "points section" in front of her. She discards any cards with no value in the 'kasu' (rubbish) pile behind the draw stack.

Next, the player draws one card from the draw stack. If it matches a card in the field, she must take the pair of cards. Otherwise, the card is left in the field. This ends that player's turn. It is possible that a player may capture as many as four cards per turn.

The player to the right takes the next turn. Play continues in this fashion until all the cards have been used in each player's hand. Points are then totaled.

Advanced play adds a wild card and also 'yaku' (bonus combinations) in special three-card combinations that are scored at the end of the game. Holding one or more yaku causes the other players to deduct points from their score, rather than adding points to the yaku-player's score.

name: Bialogue
description:
Move your token from one of the center spaces to any corner space and back again. You get to move whenever you're the first person to guess a word or phrase from clues provided by two players having a "Bialogue".

When having a "Bialogue", your goal is to get one of the other players to guess a word or phrase from a card before the timer runs out. One player says the first word of a sentence intended to provide clues about the word. The other partner says the next word, and they continue back and forth, alternating one word each time. They cannot discuss the word or the clues they're going to give. The rest of the players all try at once to guess the word or phrase. Everyone calls out ideas as fast as they can.

Tiles are earned or stolen from other players. These tiles are placed on the game board to block token movement or to remove blockages.
mechanics: Enclosure, Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game, Tile Placement

name: Sumtastic
description:
Sumtastic is a math based board game.

Single play
Solo players will play against a timer, trying to beat their own score with each play.

Multi-player
The players write their names on the score card and write a total number that the game is to be won once it is reached (example 500)

Players roll two dice, the score is then the total number which the player must move to on the playing board. A sum square is placed onto the board with the number in the center of it, around the frame are +,-,x,?. The player picks a tile randomly from the bag which must be used to complete the sum. The total is then added to the score card. The winner is the first person to reach the total.

If doubles are rolled, the players have an additional turn. If three doubles in a row are thrown the player misses a turn.

If a player removes a ? from the tile bag they may choose there own sum (substitute the ? For either a x, + or - )

Modified play
Play is available with the addition or subtraction of tiles which will effect the maths sum options.

The game is a wooden made playing board, sum frame and tiles.

name: Cirplexed!
description:
Game description from the publisher:

Cirplexed! is the quick-start game in which strategy comes full circle! Each tile features quarter circles of different colors. Each player creates her own game board by drawing and placing tiles, trying to create the most single-color circles. The game takes visual thinking and 360° of strategy to maximize your score.

name: Twenty One Turn Hero Minigame
description:
The world is in turmoil! THE SORCERER discovered a spell that will destroy the world in 21 turns! YOU as a hero need to defeat the sorcerer! Good luck hero!

This is a solo fantasy adventure game where you become the unfortunate hero that needs to defeat the sorcerer who wants to destroy the world within 21 turns. You need to battle as many monsters as possible, collect as much gold as possible, buy equipment to be stronger, and finally defeat the sorcerer (indicated at the corner right above the map), all within 21 turns.

All you need is two different tokens, a pencil, an eraser and this game.
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Paper-and-Pencil, Role Playing

name: North Star Games BGG Promo Pack
description:
North Star Games received over 500 hundred submissions from BGG users to create this promo pack. The best questions were chosen by the BGG community. This promo pack contains 28 cards with a total of:

56 Wits & Wagers Questions (8 cards with 7 questions on each)
48 Say Anything Questions (8 cards with 6 questions on each)
12 Crappy Birthday Cards
categories: Bluffing, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Party Game, Trivia

name: XIII: Le Complot
description:
(from Tilsit's page: http://www.tilsit.fr/fiches_jeux/xiii.php)

Vance and Van Hamme have created a very successful graphic novel series entitled "XIII" --it currently boasts 20 albums (along with 5 albums in it's spin-off series: XIII mystery). In Tilsit's game XIII : Le Complot based on that police/thriller world, you play each of the 27 key characters in turn. Your goal is to surmount all obstacles (traps, ambushes, plots) thrown in your way.

The board shows 33 of the albums' key locations; by traveling to each, you assemble a team able to complete a maximum of missions. Each completed mission awards you investigation points which are necessary for victory. Of course, there aren't enough missions for every player to win...

The combat encounters will be bloody, and the combined strength of your agents and characters won't be enough --you'll also need to plan your moves and play your cards right...

XIII is an amnesiac whose identity is hotly debated throughout the series. Various agencies (such as the NSA) have tentatively identified him as various notorious hit men / terrorists / secret agents --but XIII isn't an easy man to catch!
publishers: Jeux Dargaud, Tilsit, Week End Games

name: Ecology: Game of Man & Nature
description: It's your job to lead a population through four challenging ages of Civilization --- Hunting, Agricultural, Industrial and Atomic. Your goal? To survive the conflict between technology & nature and reach an ideal Environmental Age.

name: Coloraddo
description: Dice assigns a color tile, tile color placed on board with matching color but more points awarded for longest pattern (line of the same colors--a "Coloraddo") created from reverse of tile. When tiles are all on the board, the game is over and the winner is the one with the highest score.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement

name: Orbit: Rocket Race 5000
description:
The object of Orbit is to be the first to play all the cards from your hand you receive 7 cards at the beginning, 120 in total.

Taking a turn in Orbit is easy: it consists of playing a card [on the board] and taking any interactions that may result from playing this card alternatively, you may pass.

The cards must touch at least one other card along the sido or the top. The card that is played must also match all the cards it touches with the same color and/or black, which is wild.

name: Monopoly Junior: Yo-kai Watch Edition
description:
Description from the publisher:

With lots of surprises from their favorite Yo-kai characters, kids can have fun playing the Monopoly Junior: Yo-kai Watch edition game. In this simple and fast version of the Monopoly game, players move around the Jibanyan-shaped board and buy up Yo-kai game medals. Throughout the game players collect rent to buy even more Yo-kai game medals, competing to become the first player to fill their Yo-kai game watch with 5 medals and win! The game features 16 Yo-kai game medals and includes 1 exclusive Yo-kai Medal. For 2 to 4 players.

Includes gameboard, 4 character tokens, 4 Yo-kai board game watches, 16 Yo-kai board game medals, 1 exclusive Yo-kai Medal (not part of gameplay), 24 Chance cards, money pack, 2 dice, and game guide.


Yoi-kai Watch theme
Capture the Yo-kai
Includes 16 Yo-kai board game medals and one exclusive Yo-kai Medal (not part of gameplay)
Quick gameplay
Ages 5 and up
For 2 to 4 players
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Trivial Pursuit: Disney Family Edition
description:
25th anniversary edition of the famous Trivial Pursuit: A new Disney Family edition with many many questions from Fantasia, Mary Poppins, Snow White and the seven dwarfs, Prince Caspian, Wall-E and many more. Every card has a beautiful picture of the corresponding movie.

The questions vary from easy to difficult and the game contains a new feature; action cards.

name: Husky
description:
In Husky, players take roles as mushers in a race through Alaska.

Players present movement cards from their hands to press their mushers towards the finish line. The movement of a musher is based on the current weather, which is determined at the beginning of each turn. Players also move animals with the goal of attempting to "attack" other mushers. When a musher is attacked, he/she loses a turn. There are also event cards that add some variation to movement and gameplay.

Throughout the game players must move through each checkpoint before proceeding further in the race. The first person to reach the finish is the victor.

name: Mission Critical: Mars
description:
From the Box:
Work together as a team of astronauts on a thrilling journey to Mars! Face dangerous emergencies and solve problems together as the electronic Command Computer narrates your adventure. It will take teamwork, strategy and a little luck to guide your spacecraft to a successful landing on the Red Planet!

From the Instructions:
Your team of brave astronauts has accepted a perilous mission to Mars. It is vital that the astronauts stay healthy and perform Mission Tasks throughout the journey in preparation for the difficult Mars Landing.

Space is full of hazards, and emergencies are common. When the Command Computer sounds the alarm, the clock starts ticking. The team must quickly assess the situation and execute the correct Emergency Procedure. The team wins only if the ship survives the journey, and the crew successfully executes the Mars Landing Procedure.

The game can end one of three ways.

Spacecraft is Destroyed
If the players fail four Emergency Procedures, the spacecraft takes more damage than it can sustain and is destroyed. The players lose the game.

Landing Procedure Fails
If the players are not able to successfully complete the Mars Landing Procedure before time runs out, the landing vehicle crashing on to the surface of Mars. The players lose the game.

Landing Procedure Succeeds
If the players successfully complete the Mars Landing Procedure, then its time to celebrate a successful mission. The players win the game!

name: Sorry! Sliders Pocket Game
description:
from Publisher blurb

Sorry Sliders Pocket Game - Aim, slide and score your way to victory! Set out the double-sided discs and slide your pawns to hit just the right mark. But watch out your opponent could knock you out of your perfect spot! Hit the points zones to start racking them up and avoid the danger zones, where your score could slide down to zero. Test your skill on the easy side of the discs first and then flip them over for an even bigger challenge! When your game is done, pack up your pawns and discs into the carry-case and take your sliding skills on the go.

Sorry Sliders Pocket Game includes:
6 pawns
5 Double-sided play-discs
Carry-case
Instructions

name: Die, Robot, Die!
description:
In Die, Robot, Die! players command an army of 8 robots, represented by dice. The game is played on a grid, with each player having a "base" on their side of the grid. The object of the game is to either destroy the opponent's base, destroy the opponent's entire army, or make it so that none of the opponent's army can move on their turn.

On a player's turn, first a player may sabotage the opponent's base (if they have a die alone in the opponent's base), which reduces the health of the base. If the players destroys the base in this manner, they win.

A player must then move one of their armies according to the pips shown on the dice. If the player has no legal move, he loses.

Lastly, a player may attack one of the opponent's dice, with the attacker gaining pips, and the defender losing pips according to the pips currently showing on the dice. If a die is reduced to 0 or less pips in the battle, that army is eliminated from the game. If a die ends up getting too many pips, that army is "overloaded" and dies as well!

Die, Robot Die! is contained in the centerfold of Spielbox Magazine, Issue #3 of 2012. You will need to supply your own dice and tokens to play.

name: Drachenlachen
description:
The players are dwarves who try to steal golden rings from the dragon's lair in the middle of the game board and carry them out of the dragon's cave.
Players take turns rolling one die, moving the corresponding number of steps:
- if they are carrying a ring, they move towards the exit
- if they are not carrying a ring, they move towards the center of the cave.
When two dwarves meet and one is carrying a ring and the other isn't, the one whose turn it is kicks the other one out of the cave (stealing his ring first, if applicable).
Whenever a "1" is rolled, the dragon laughs. The active player then rolls two dice to determine two or more fields (such as 31 and 13, for instance - special rules apply for rolling doubles). All dwarves on these fields lose their rings and are kicked out of the cave. The first player who carries two rings out of the cave is the winner.

The game is entirely dice driven, there is no decision-making involved.

name: Scrabble Overturn
description:
Fundamentally, Scrabble Overturn is a scoring variant on Scrabble (q.v.)

The board is a simple grid, into which one places "letter cylinders" which depict a given letter in four colors. If a player employs existing cylinders in making a word, those cylinders are rotated to show the active player's color.

Words are scored as played if they score a minimum of 12 points (otherwise zero points) with a bonus for playing all seven cylinders in one turn. A final end-game score is added to individual player scores, but only for words that are all of one color. Multi-color words may be broken down into segments and scored if they are also valid words.

name: Latador
description:
Latador is a game designed by Magnús Scheving, based on his play Latibær (which later became a cartoon show called Lazytown.) In Latador the player rolls a die and goes along the track and he has to follow the instructions on each step he lands on, healthy lifestyle and dexterity helps you win the game.

The name Latador is a homage to the Icelandic version of Monopoly which is called Matador. Along the way you can earn money, get few types of cards which can help you or others where you have to move or tell the thruth about your lifestyle.
mechanics: Acting, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Oak Hills  The First Battle in the West
description: The game is one of five in the War for Southern Independence Series. This is a simulation of the First Battle of the Civil War in the West: Oak Hills (also known as Wilson's Creek)in August 1861. The game uses a a bombardment chart and a single d10 combat system with modifications for terrain and odds. Units are counters of infantry, cavalry, and artillery. The game is based on the old Civil War SPI quad system. The Series uses a set of standard rules and special rules that apply to each battle. Map scale varies from 176 to 450 yards depending on the game. Other games in the series are: Elkhorn Tavern, Fort Donelson, Iuka, and Prairie Grove.

name: Turkupeli
description:
This is the Turku version of the Kaupunkipelit (City Games) series. The southwestern city of Turku is the oldest city in Finland (founded 1229), was the capital before Helsinki until 1812, and still is the 6th largest city and the hub of the 3rd largest metropolitan area in the country, the capital of it's region, and an important seaport with shipyards.

Unlike most games in the series, this one (along with Helsinkipeli) came in two different editions; an earlier edition in a styrofoam box inside a cardboard sleeve fastened by velcro (similar to the concurrent Swedish Lokalspelet series) and a later edition which is similar to most of the other games in the series.

Kaupunkipelit is a series of games, each of which is basically a light version of Monopoly localized to a city/region of Finland. The games promote local companies, councils, educational institutes etc. and were designed as a fund raising effort for local sports clubs.

The main differences between these games and Monopoly are:

-Instead of a "street" each square on the board represents a local business.
-There are no hotels or houses, but each square has two title deeds instead of just one, allowing two players to jointly own any location on the board.
-The majority of the event cards are trivia questions about the locality the game is set in.
-While the effects of the first two corner squares (Go and Jail in Monopoly) remain the same for every edition (Go and Stock Market Crash), the effect of the other two corners varies from edition to edition and is the only real difference between them (except for the trivia content, of course). They are typically also local businesses but without title deeds and thus no rent either, but some special effect instead, such as pass a turn or get an extra throw.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Income, Loans, Lose a Turn, Ownership, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Track Movement, Trading

name: Karé Dément
description: A French abstract game similar to Chinese Checkers in that you are trying to get your pieces from side to the other, and so are your opponents.

name: NYA Familjens Frågespel
description: Experience the laughter and excitement in the family's favorite quiz. This way is on issues of 385 fun topics about everything between heaven and earth, from animals in Africa and signed figure to mobile phones and planets. The questions fit the flesta and there is some addition, special issues for the youngest. Answering questions in your favorite subject and try to win as much money as possible on your skills. When the timer starts ticking, you have 15 seconds to respond. While stress co pillars you through placing the chance cards which means they probably know the answer and want to "steal" your question. The player with the most money at the end of the game will be the family champion.

name: Sneak Attack
description:
From the description of the game:
"When war comes, humans no longer man the battlefield. Wars are fought by mechs, giant robots, remotely controlled from far-away bases, with the riders of these giant mechs completely out of harms way.

Nonetheless, your commanding officers have a job for you. A job putting you in the line of real danger. Intel suggests that the enemy has amassed a large force, and put them ashore outside your capital in the midst of night. Their mission? To launch nuclear missiles at your nations leader, and every monument in your capital.

Our engineers have sent out a signal that interrupts the mech's connection with their home base, causing them to wander meanlessly around.

Now, you must sneak out to destroy each of the enemies' mechs, before they are powered up and ready to launch.But be careful."

Sneak Attack is a free, print-to-play game designed for the "sneaky sci-fi game contest".
During play, you will move around a hexagonal board depicting a battlefield. The player will attempt to sneak up on enemy mechs, destroying them with EMP charges, in order to save their home, and the pride of their country.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Push 4
description:
Up to four players push their colored marbles into the 6x6 grid board in order to get four-in-a-row first.

Contents:

Matt black plastic 3D game board
36 bright fluorescent balls
Drawstring bag for storing game pieces


Product Dimensions: 2 x 10 x 10 inches

Item Weight: 2 pounds

Released: 01 October 2010

ASIN: B00421BD7W

Item model number: 2100104

From the Manufacturer:

"When push comes to shove be the first to get four colorful marbles in a row. Sounds simple. Not with pushy opponents spoiling your every move. There’s a lot of strategy involved in this deceptively simple game. Push4 is perfect for 2-4 players and fun for all ages 9 to adult."

Manufacturer: Summit By White Mountain (Summit Products, Inc. ???)

name: CryptidsTV
description:
CryptidsTV, a new type of party game, challenges players to create new television shows, with them taking part in all aspects of a show's production meetings – drawing, talking and being creative – with the aim of getting their show on prime time. Part of the challenge comes from being presented with two separate concepts drawn from separate card decks – for example, a liquid creature and a fad that appeals to kids – and figuring out how to merge these concepts creatively into a single creation.

Each player takes one role card and reveals it to indicate his role for the game. The assistant director distributes pens and creation sheets to players.

In each round, the director randomly selects one Cryptids card, such as "vehicle creature", then everybody must draw a creature representing this category within one minute. The assistant director redistributes the drawings among players (with players not being allowed to look at them), then the director randomly selects one Show card, such as "The creature is able to communicate and converse with humans! What is the secret behind it?" Each player then makes his presentation using the caption and drawing in hand.

Players then vote on the winning presentation by simultaneously pointing to the show they thought best, with the director breaking ties. The winner is selected to air on prime time, with the player who drew the cryptid receiving the prime time tile, and its reporter receiving the prime time host tile. Everyone gives them a round of applause.

Play four rounds total with 3-6 players, and only three rounds with seven or more players. End the game by kibitzing over the suggestions that were botched and didn't merit air time.

Can be combined with the material in the sequel CryptidsTV 2.
categories: Animals, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Real-time, Science Fiction, Word Game
mechanics: Line Drawing, Paper-and-Pencil, Role Playing, Storytelling, Voting

name: 1955 Local Mercenary Promo Card
description: This expansion/promotion was a reward for the original Kickstarter supporters of 1955. It consists in two identical cards that can be added to the deck. A player may use this card to add three to his influence in the country in which his spy is located.

name: The Eight-headed Dragon OROCHI
description:
User summary:
真説 大蛇のえじき (Shinsetsu Orochi no Ejiki), in English means "Victims of the Serpent: The True Story", is published with the English name The Eight-headed Dragon OROCHI.

Shinsetsu Orochi no Ejiki is a card game based on Yamata no Orochi Legends in Japanese mythology.

A game consists of seven rounds. Each round, players receive three human cards, each numbered 1-3, and one random special character card (Orochi, Susanoo, Oracle, Hermit, etc). They play one card simultaneously. If no one play Orochi, humans are safe and players who played a human with the lowest number score points. If Orochi is in play, humans are dead and the Orochi player scores points, but if both Orochi and Susanoo are in play, Susanoo slays Orochi and saves humans, and the Susanoo player steals points from the Orochi player. The game goes to next round after Orochi was played.
Players should predict opponents' moves to score points and win the game.

Publisher's summary:
日本神話の「ヤマタノオロチ伝説」を題材に、人狼系＆バッティングゲーム。7ラウンドで構成されたゲームで1ラウンドは最大4回プレイします。
プレイヤーはラウンド毎に１~３の基本カードとオロチやスサノオ、巫女、山伏など様々な役職を担当のカードを受け取ります。
ラウンド内でも得点が多い日もあれば少ない日もあります。
一番小さな数字のカードを出したプレイヤーが得点を得ます。
でも、オロチと一緒に出されるとオロチに食べられ、得点をオロチに持って行かれます。スサノオとオロチが同時に出るとオロチは倒されスサノオが得点を稼ぎます。このように、他のプレイヤーの動きを読みながら、より多くの得点の獲得を目指すゲームです。
publishers: Joynt Game Factory (ジョイントゲームファクトリー)

name: Canine Chaos
description:
Canine Chaos is a card game featuring dogs. Use Toys, Treats, and Tricks to train your Dogs and cause chaos in other packs. Become the first player to build a pack of 5 Dogs. For a more challenging game, be the first to reach 7 dogs.

To start a turn, pack owners draw one card from the deck. pack owners may add one Dog into their pack per turn as a free action. During a turn, pack owners may also use an already learned Trick, or use an Alpha Trait. The turn ends when pack owner makes one of the following moves:

Play a Dog Toy
Play a Power Card
Buy or attempt to lure a dog out of The Street or The Shelter
Use Treats to teach a dog a Trick
Change the Alpha Dog in their pack
Discard their hand and draw five new cards
Voluntarily choose to end the turn


Alpha Traits: Each Dog has a special ability that can only be used when the dog is the Alpha Dog. Alpha traits allow pack owners to bend certain rules, and only become usable once the pack owner has an Alpha Dog and at least one additional dog in their pack.
Tricks and Treats: Each dog can learn a certain numbers of tricks, which is noted on the Dog Card. Tricks give pack owners an extra edge in the game. This can be by defending a pack against other pack owner’s moves, giving a pack owner the chance to look at other pack owners’ cards, take cards from other pack owners, or giving a better chance at rescuing a Dog from The Street or The Shelter.
Rolling Dice: Certain cards require a roll of the die to decide if the card's effect is successful, and some cards increase or decrease the number required for a successful roll. For example, the “Rubber Chicken” card requires a die roll of 4 or higher to save the Dog from being taken by an opposing pack owner. However, all XL dogs take a -2 to all rolls against the Rubber Chicken. If this card was played against a Great Dane, and the pack owner rolled a 5, this modification would mean the roll counted as a 3. The Great Dane would be taken by the opposing pack owner. Alternatively, the Trick “Sit!” adds a +1 to any roll. A Great Dane that knows “Sit!” would be safe from the Rubber Chicken card because the total roll would be a 4.

name: Tiny Trees
description:
Tiny Trees is a competitive tree-building board game designed for 2-4 players, where you play as a minor nature spirit trying to become the next Demigod of Trees! Unlike a lot of board games that lie flat on your table, the trees you grow branch out of your table and into the third dimension.

The way the game works is that you start with a trunk and some roots, and you take turns slotting together hexagonal cards, called branchlets, so that by the end of the game, you’ll have something that looks like an actual tree!

Then, depending on how you grew your tree, you earn favor, or points, for a variety of factors, with the spirit who earns most wins and becomes the next demigod of trees! From the moment you open up the box, you’ll be creating something you can be proud of. So now go out and grow some trees.

—description from the designer

name: Lost at Sea
description:
This is one of the games featured in Dice & Ink: A Roll & Write Anthology, and exists as part of that compilation.

In Lost at Sea, you are the sole survivor of a shipwreck, stranded upon an island of trash. Here, you are trying desperately to stay healthy among the filth and lack of fresh water, with no food or shelter. Can you stay alive long enough to build a raft and escape? This solitaire game with worker placement elements will prove a challenge.

Each turn consists of two phases: a Day phase and a Night phase. Take action during the Day phase, suffer the consequences of your actions so far in the Night phase, which serves as upkeep.

On your turn:

During the Day phase, roll the dice,
Then group and assign the dice to actions; each action requires dice of a specific combined value:
Rest to increase your health, clean to keep the filth off of yourself at least, collect pieces of garbage to help you build tools and a raft, fish for food, and build things to help you survive, such as water catchers or a shelter.
During the Night phase, your hygiene and health worsen (or improve) depending on whether you have food, if your water is clean, and how you are faring overall.
This game is tough in a way that makes you want to play it again, because you know you could do better than you did the last time!

Lost at Sea requires five standard six-sided dice of one color and one single standard six-sided die of another color. Components include one player sheet.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Line Drawing, Paper-and-Pencil, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Marry the Monster
description:
You are a duke trying to build up your lands where the monstrous fachan is rampaging. But he is just lonely. Your cunning plan is to make a false bride for him just behind your rivals’ buildings. The love-struck monster will crash through the other dukes’ lands, destroying them, while you continue to build up yours!
Marry the Monster is a game for 3 to 5 players in which each player scores points by building structures and having them remain until your next turn without being destroyed by the monster. Turns are taken by playing cards, and there is no upkeep phase – play simply continues until there is a winner.'
mechanics: Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, King of the Hill, Resource to Move, Take That, Zone of Control

name: New Phone, Who Dis?: Family Edition
description:
Players rotate drawing a sent (or “inbox”) card while the rest of the group competes to play the funniest “reply” card. Once everyone has played their chosen reply card, the rotating judge awards a point to the funniest one. The player with the most points at the end of the round wins.

Includes: 240 family-friendly Inbox cards, 300 family-friendly Reply cards, and instructions.

name: Space Dandy: Galactic Deck-Building Game
description:
A new take on the deck-building genre, featuring the zany universe of the hit show Space Dandy as seen on ADULT SWIM.

That's right, baby! Dandy has gone and used the Aloha Oe's broken warp drive and managed to converge every possible alternate universe into one, causing multiple copies of everyone in the known galaxies to run amok! What does this mean for our intrepid heroes? Will all semblance of civilization fall into disorder and chaos? Will the universe, under the weight of so many simultaneous timelines, implode on itself into a cosmic Big Bang?

Well. Maybe. But for now it means the Alien Registration Center has reset the database and is allowing new registration of all previously registered aliens! That's cold, hard Woolong just out there for the taking, baby!

The Space Dandy: Galactic Deck-Building Game brings the bizarre space-faring antics of the hit anime series seen on ADULT SWIM TOONAMI to the game table. It's similar to other Deck-Builders like Dominion and Ascension—with an extra helping of phantom space ramen goodness. Each player begins the game with the same rather low-powered starting cards, but through careful play, you can acquire more to expand your options. Which cards you choose to take directly influence the kind of game you play!

Cards can grant new abilities, make it easier to acquire new cards, allow you to take extra turns, or even destroy cards from the game altogether! But the most important cards are the aliens. Not only can they improve your hand just like any other card, they can be played Planetside and directly attack the other Player. Why fiddle around endlessly with your deck when you can stick it to them and mess up their carefully laid plans? That's the Dandy way to play!

Even more importantly, aliens are how you win! When you register aliens, they are removed from play, but you get to score precious, precious Woolong that you need to win the game. But be careful! It can be difficult to decide if an alien is more useful in your hand, on the Planet, or in the Alien Registration Center's bank.

That’s not to say the other cards aren’t important, too! Effect Cards cannot be registered OR played Planetside, but they let you manipulate the game to your advantage. Sick of that really great card the opponent keeps playing? DESTROY IT! Changed your mind about the card you played Planetside? WARP IT BACK! Keep your opponent’s on their toes with your carefully constructed (or hazardously haphazard) deck!

You can also fill out your space crew with other humans (and the occasional robot) that can’t be registered as aliens (obviously). But never fear! They make up for the lack of Woolong delivery with unique abilities of their own!

So register those aliens, earn all the Woolong you can, and may the Best Dandy Win!
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Space Exploration

name: The Adventure of Hayabusa
description:
User summary:

The adventure of Hayabusa is a co-operative card game for 1–4 players. The space probe Hayabusa has just fetched samples from another planet and is journeying back to Earth, when trouble after trouble occurs. The players play the roles of the crew and the mission is to overcome the problems and guide Hayabusa back to the Earth safely. All players draw cards from the same deck, and discuss which cards to add to the deck, all the while problem cards are gradually added to the deck.

Designed by Makoto Nakamura, the designer of Gashbell the Card Battle.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building

name: Lemmings in Space
description: Hex-and-miniature game in which players fly spaceships filled with lemmings around the game area hoping to intentionally kill off their entire crew as quickly as possible. The trick is, upgrading your ship and exploration (which may lead to successes rather than failures) are the best ways to approach your doom faster. As your ship grows more powerful, you make a better target, but you'll do more damage to other players' ships. The objective is to lose all 28 members of your crew.
publishers: Inner City Games Designs, Truant Spiele

name: The Decathlon Games
description: This game is a card game which features the 10 Decathlon events and past champions. Each player is dealt a number of athlete cards which have actual medal winners on them with their results from various events. An event card is flipped up and then each player plays an athlete card containing a result for that event. Scores are compared and points are awarded.
publishers: Random Games, The United States Playing Card Company

name: The Great Dragon Hunt
description:
The Great Dragon Hunt is a great kids game with lots of gameboard action.

The players are Knights who must each roam the land to capture 10 different dragons. At the start of the game each player is dealt one coloured dragon card... that becomes their first target.

Players spin and move by complete count. If they land on a dragon space that matches the colour of their dragon, they 'capture' it and draw another card. If they land, by exact count, on another player, they send him back to his home castle.

The board contains a number of plastic 'drawbridges' that are either up or down. They may only be crossed if they are lying flat. Boats also exist that may allow a move of close to 1/2 of the board.

name: Battle Flag TCG
description: Solo American civil war card game. Every turn draw cards until you have four cards in your hand, you decide when to play the good and bad ones. But end a turn with four cards and you lose. Primarily you place cards into play, pushing toward the enemy general. Use flanking,charging, artillery with your line formations. Free print and play, 40 cards in all, plus rules. A quick play game with no bean counting or dice rolling.
categories: American Civil War, Card Game, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Hand Management, Solo / Solitaire Game, Tile Placement

name: Beeren klau'n mit Schnabelgrün
description:
Raven Schnabelgrün loves blueberries. He flies around and picks up as many as possible.
To play, set up a circly of meadow tiles - they are lake tiles on the other side. Randomly distribute the large wooden blueberries on the tiles (up to three per tile). Schnabelgrün starts on one of the tiles. The active player draws a card which determines the distance the raven can move (1, 2 or 3 tiles). The player then picks up any blueberries on that tile. If there are none, the player flips over an empty meadow tile instead. If Schnabelgrün lands on a lake tile, the active player needs to put down two blueberries on that field to help the raven stay afloat. Some cards also let the player steal a berry from another player.
The game ends when a player runs out of berries. The player with most berries is the winner.

name: Monopoly: Street Fighter Collector's Edition
description:
Enter the world of one of the best selling video game franchises of all time in this special Street Fighter Collector’s Edition of Monopoly. Buy, sell and trade fighting arenas associated with the most iconic characters over 25 years such as Makoto in the Karate Dojo, Ryu on the Rooftops of Japan and Major Bison in the Shadaloo Headquarters.

While custom art and clever SF shout-outs are indeed a welcome addition, the best part about this customized version is the final 6 collectible Street Fighter-themed tokens, which were voted by fans. : Ryu, Major Bison, Blanka, Hadoken, Chun-Li’s Wrist Cuff and Vega’s Mask.

Custom game board features iconic fighting arenas from the Street Fighter video game franchise covering 25 years. Traditional Houses & Hotels are renamed Training Rooms and Dojos. “Bonus Stage” & “Random Select” cards replace classic Community Chest & Chance Cards.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Welt der Spiele
description:
Game description from the publisher:

What picture exists in the card game Tarot? What is special about the blue Mikado sticks? How many game pieces does each player get in the game of Nine Men's Morris? Welt der Spiele is all about the most popular board, dice and card games, including game authors, publishers and much more, for in the words of the famous German poet and philosopher Friedrich Schiller: "It is play and only play that makes man complete."

name: Legends of Adventure
description:
Legends of Adventure is a cooperative fantasy board game that streamlines the role-playing experience for newcomers to the genre, people who have limited time for gaming, and those who just want to play a lighter style of game. Players attempt to cooperatively complete 10 adventures in order to become Legends. To do so, all the players must work together to defeat Monsters along the way. Each time you play is unique, and the game is enhanced by magnificent fantasy artwork.

To play Legends of Adventure, players become Heroes of different types and go forth to undertake up to 10 adventures. To complete each adventure, the Heroes must defeat a group of Monsters equal in number to the number of players. The assorted adventures and the Monsters provide circumstances and powers that modify game play. In order to defeat the Monsters and complete each adventure, the players must jointly outscore the Monsters’ combined level. This is done by rolling unique dice, featuring water, fire, and forest icons, for the levels of Heroes and Treasure Cards played, as well as playing Divine Intervention cards, adding an interesting spin that allows Heroes to request help from the gods. Each successful die roll adds to the overall score of the Heroes; once the Heroes have defeated the Monsters, they receive loot in the form of Treasure Cards that will help them in future adventures. The variety of cards provides different scenarios not only for all adventures but also for each game as a whole.

name: Last Word Standing
description:
Last Word Standing pits 2 to 6 players against each other in a fast-paced war of the words! Players use letter cards to spell high-value words that beat out the competition to the highest score — or else lose half their own points in the fray! With action cards to turn the tables, swap cards, steal letters, and more, whether you're a quick speller or a long-term strategizer, in the end, it's not about who's the wordiest, but just who has the last word standing!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Open Drafting, Set Collection, Take That

name: Search History
description:
Search History is the only party game that uses real searches in it’s hilarious and unique gameplay.

Read one of three prompts aloud and compete with friends and family to anonymously create the most believable search query.

Take turns guessing what the most commonly searched phrase is and score points if your answer is guessed by others.

Combine with the NSFW Edition for even more fun!

—description from the publisher

name: Aliados: por ahora...
description:
From the website:
"In the game are general knowledge questions and situations of personal connection. Participants choose a temporary ally with whom to solve each activity.

If you answer about history, sports, nature, or agree on ice cream flavors, or how to react in case of being kidnapped by a pirate ship... the ally of your choice... may be different."

Trivia route where the only way forward is taking allies with others players.

You chose a temporary ally to answer a question, if both says the correct answer, both move one square from the board. You must select who are the perfect ally for each situation... but if s/he is in first place, do you answer with him/her?
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Open Drafting, Team-Based Game

name: Nos w nos
description:
Nos w nos (Nose in nose) consists of three games for one to four children aged 4 to 8. All the games revolve around recognition of six smells, included in the game in the form of small samples. Although games are based on simple concepts of memory or image recognition, introduction of olfactory components create different experience.

Box contents: six small plastic containers with pellets emanating 6 different odors (rose, soap, green apple, smoke, grass and spearmint), 24 cardboard tiles (6 sets of tiles depicting four different things or scenes related to one of the included smells), and small poster with instructions overleaf.

name: Yam Yam
description:
Yam Yam is a card game that lets young children decide how much longer their hedgehog family can safely stay outside to eat before snow suddenly starts to fall.

Before the beginning of winter, all hedgehogs have to be fast asleep. As soon as a hedgehog sleeps, however, it can no longer help gather food. That's why you will have to think twice after each food card that you draw — whether it really is time already for another one of your hedgehogs to hibernate.

Contents:
60 game cards, divided into:
16 hedgehog cards in 4 colors
40 food cards
4 winter cards

name: O'Kudos
description:
O'Kudos is a small promotional game that was available from the designer at Essen 2005 and as a Christmas card.

The O’Kudos board is a completed Sudoku puzzle. Each of the nine areas is represented by nine small numbered squares of a unique colour. Depending on the number of players, each player is secretly assigned either two or three of these coloured areas. By placing counters on the board, each player attempts to cover up as many of their opponents’ numbered squares as possible. At the end of the game players score the value of the numbers in their own coloured areas that have not been covered up. The player (or the ‘game’ if it has also been assigned colours) with the highest score is the winner.
publishers: R&D Games, W. Nostheide Verlag GmbH

name: The Count Duckula Game
description:
Count Duckula the vegetarian vampire is on a mission to find four treasures that have been buried around the world by one of his distant cousins.

It’s a memory game where both friends and foes can get in the way of count Duckula’s way. There’s also the unreliable castle that can teleport around the world.
categories: Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip, Fantasy, Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Memory, Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move
publishers: MB Giochi, MB spel, MB Spiele, Milton Bradley

name: Charly at the Zoo
description:
From the manufacturer:

Quack, quack! Charly is amazed by all the animals in the zoo. However, through the peepholes of the enclosures Charly can only see parts of the animals. Who will help Charly recognize them correctly? A memory game demanding close observation for 2-5 players.

For ages 4 and up.

name: Ab ins Bett, Nils!
description:
Bertie doesn’t want to go to bed; he wants to play just a bit longer. So the children play with him!

The little hippo shows children a first color identification and memory game.

name: Renault F1 Team
description:
Renault F1 Team
The official licensed Board Game
Welcome to the exhilarating world of Fornmula 1 racing!
The circuits are divided into spaces and the players advance their cars using speed cards. Each card indicates how many spaces a car has to move. Excessive speed, braking or cornering at high speed may reduce the efficiency of your car up to the point where it breaks down and you have to retire.

Tha game contains one mounted board with two circuits (Montecarlo and Sakhir), 20 colored plastic cars, 20 driver cards, 90 speed cards, 4 dice, a timer (used to measure the length of pit stops in the advanced rules version) and 5 rules booklets (one per language)

name: Memory Challenge: National Parks Edition
description:
Publisher Blurb:

Uncover the beauty of America’s National Parks with the world’s most popular matching game including over 100 picture cards featuring beautiful photography and park names. Rules & Regulations cards create all new game play action allowing players to swipe matches, take extra turns and peek at more cards. Players can become a National Park specialist, such as a Geologist or Historian, and score extra points for matches made within their specialty. It’s an adventure to remember for families who love the great outdoors.

name: Professor Crocodile's Safari School
description:
In Safari School you have to give the animals the right characteristics before your opponents.

Choose between 22 characteristics such as "Got wings" and "Eats plants". The first player who reach 15 points wins.

Other variations are possible depending on the number of players.

name: Pim Pam Pet cardgame
description:
Players draw a category card and read the topic. Then they draw the letter-card instead of turning the wheel like in original Pim-Pam-Pet. Everyone is trying as quickly as possible to find a word that matches the subject and with that specific letter in start, in end or in middle of the word etc.

A good answer is rewarded by a chip in the color of the question.
Who at the end of the game has scored the most points is the winner.

name: Tracker: A Post Nuclear Disaster
description:
Years after the apocalypse, a group of survivors is locked in battle for the astonishing power of artefacts. In a constantly changing environment, they must adapt their strategy and tactics — but much more is required to be the very best...

Tracker: A Post Nuclear Disaster is a competitive post-apocalyptic board game in which even the dead still have a chance at winning. Each player starts in one of the six Shelters. When all have spawned, the first mission objective is revealed. Afterwards it's a race from corner to corner of hexagons but the players must decide whether their priority is to arm themselves, rush to finish a mission, or venture inside an anomaly to pick up artefacts, i.e., power ups.

Missions and artefacts are worth points, but so is killing and looting other players. When the first player collects the set amount of winning points or is the last living player, he is declared the winner.

If at any point of the game you get killed, you respawn as a zombie. The gameplay changes a little bit and you must hunt down at least one player to be able to respawn as a living player. This means that the game does not end when you die, and you can still win the game.
mechanics: Player Elimination, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Night of Horror Dice
description:
You are a half-blood between vampire and werewolf. You have power! You can be a vampire! A werewolf! A human! You are one of the most powerful creatures in history — but you were too powerful. All humans, vampires and werewolves are now searching for you to kill. You lost your home, parents, friends, everything by them. There is nothing left except bloody revenge.

The Night of Horror Dice is a simple dice game. You have three health points for each turn. First, choose your ability. You can use one ability from human, vampire and werewolf. Each abilities has unique effects. Then, pick up three enemy dices from pouch and throw. As the result you gain or lose your health, catch them or they might runaway.
